Title / subject: Bite on the Haynes Nano Stage
Notes: Sculpture marks the site of, and honours, the Paperback bookshop, and its owner Jim Haynes,that was once was located on Charles St. The Rhino head makes reference to a taxidermy Rhino Head that hung outside the entrance to the bookshop. The stainless steel book called Bite honours the Paperback bookshop, and its owner Jim Haynes,that was once was located on Charles St. The pixelated form speaks to the tension between digital and non-digital culture. It is sited on a low white wall retitled by the artist as the Haynes Nano Stage, honouring Haynes’ involvement in theatre and festivals in Edinburgh.

Former principal of the University of Edinburgh, Brewster is credited for the invention of the Kaleidoscope and stereoscope. Wearing contemporary academic garb, Brewster’s outstretched hand once held a prism referencing his work in physics and lens.
Erected by Leith Town Council [62]
Unveiled 18 January 1917 at St Andrew Square by the Earl of Rosebery. Moved to this, its original intended location, in 1955.[63]
Unveiled 22 July 1986 by Suganya Chetty.[64]
Commission by Baillie Gifford as part of Percent for art scheme

Title / subject: La Vierge d'Alsace(The Virgin of Alsace)
The Next Big Thing…Is A Series of Little Things
Notes: As though someone had walked across the square with a leaking tin of paint, a trail of bronze stretches from the original entrance to McEwan Hall across Bristo Square.

Embedded in the ground outside the library is a circular mesostic poem. Mesostic is the term given to a one lined poem inspired by a stem word or name source that is distinguishably highlighted within it. Emphasised by dots are the letters that form the quote ‘thair to remain’, taken from the will of the library’s first benefactor.

Title / subject: The Basic Material Is Not the Word But the Letter
Notes: Commissioned to mark the 50th Anniversary of the Main Library, the exact meaning of the chosen phrase – which was found by the artist in the University’s archive – is open to the interpretation of those viewing it.

Commissioned in memory of Dr Winifred Rushforth. Two stones stand facing each other. The torso of a woman in semi relief has been carved into inside one of the stones. Eyes are closed and she cups her left ear. On the stone directly opposite is a hollow form of a woman carved into the stone in a primitive style.
Low, circular stone. Gifted to the University by Furuta after he completed a residency at the University of Edinburgh

A Viking age Swedish runestone in Edinburgh with an interesting story to tell is on the move!
For years, the runestone was largely unknown and inaccessible to residents and visitors alike, despite being located in the heart of the city. It had been left high on a steep hillside just below the north wall of Edinburgh Castle’s esplanade.
More recently, it was completely off limits during the summer months due to the installation of high metal railings and locked gates to protect the large supporting columns of the stadium for the annual Military Tattoo.
In 2018, this unique piece of shared Scottish-Swedish heritage will be unveiled in a new, safer location in the city: accessible and easy to find for all. What do the runes say?
The inscription starts at the head of the snake and runs clockwise. It follows a standard formula and contains sentiment common on late Viking Age Swedish memorials: a son commemorating his father together with a prayer.
The University of Edinburgh Memorial to over 1,000 staff, students and alumni that died during the First and Second World Wars.
6ft High gold gilted bronze. Sculpture of nude male holding torch intended to act as a symbol of learning. Modelled on Edinburgh boxer, Anthony Hall.

James Howden’s giant sucker darts make a playful yet critical point about our social and cultural relationship with war and violence. Referencing the form of toy gun bullets, they elude to the apparent double standard in society; where war and violence are condemned yet seemingly also normalised through toys, video games and play.

Memorial to ECA staff and students who died during the First World War. An incomplete list of names on scroll is kept in simply decorated bronze casket on stone plinth. Funded by staff, students and friends.

One of the world’s few remaining cast collections, acquired at the end of the 19th century as a teaching collection to illustrate Classical art history. The Edinburgh Cast Collection comprises 265 plaster casts of Antique, Renaissance, and Gothic statues, bas reliefs, and architectural passages and includes a beautiful neo-Classical sculpture court specifically designed to house the casts of the Parthenon frieze.
Two raw sandstone rocks represent the University and its secure environment. Nearby, a third rock symbolises the cutting edge of the real world.
Set of sculptures gifted to the University as part of Furuta’s residency.

Title / subject: Let my Blood be the Seed of My Freedom
Notes: This is a tribute to Archbishop of San Salvador Oscar Romero who was murdered in March 1980, as part of renaming of Pollock Hall Developemnt as Romero Place.
Dr Huang Kuan (Wong Fun) was one of the first Chinese to study in Europe. After completing his medical degree at the University of Edinburgh c.1855-7, he returned to China to practice medicine.

One of two monumental bronze figures first installed in front of Molecular Biology's new Swann Building in 1997. The figures, now located outside the Murray Library, are deconstructed and reconstructed, a metaphor of molecular biology, and they are acrobats or jugglers, an image of the skill and dexterity of the scientist. The pair’s names derived from planets seen in an illustration in a book on Newton.

The figures, now located outside the Murray Library, are deconstructed and reconstructed, a metaphor of molecular biology, and they are acrobats or jugglers, an image of the skill and dexterity of the scientist. A series of roundels on the Kings Buildings Ashworth Buildings containing reliefs of invertebrates and animals representing the principal zoogeographical regions used at the time of the original commission
The figurative relief carving to the principal gable, depicting a male figure using some kind rudimentary rotary equipment against the backdrop of a wheel.

Sited above the doorway into the University's Grant Institute. The allegorical figure of 'Geology' is seated on slabs of sandstone, which at the same time look like books. He is studying the fossil of an ammonite in his left hands while the entire composition is neatly enclosed within a larger ammonite motif.

The figurative relief carving to the building's principal gable is a distinctive feature of the entrance elevation. The relief depicts a child on a pedestal over a stylised fountain and a man and woman holding antique oil lamps up towards the child.

Stone sculpture of a horse, lying on the ground about to rise as if startled. This horse was originally located at the top of the Clyde Street Veterinary College building, later abandoned for the School's next location at Summerhall. It was moved to Easter Bush in 2007.
Sculpture of former Vetinary surgeon and founder of Dick Vet School William Dick, seated. Previously located at Summerhall and relocated to Easter Bush when Vet School moved.
Sprinting afghan hound, hair flowing behind it viewed from one side, sprinting skeleton only from the other side. Head complete to both sides.
